content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I really enjoyed it. There are details that are easy to overlook for clashers who jump straight to coding without reading the description carefully, but it's all there.
Approving this one. It's easy to overlook the details on a quick reading, but the description is clear on a careful read. That's not a problem and maybe even desirable in Clash of Code.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Approved had fun with this one and thought it was a lot simpler at 1st glace nice and right level difficulty

Thumbs up!
Comment: In the first line, you are not trying to find "the most IMPORTANT adjective of", but just "the adjective of the first noun". That line tripped me up and made me think that I needed to maybe check which adjectives to return before the given noun

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Enjoyed coding this one. Original and creative. Seems pretty simple at first glance, but there are some nuances that must be paid attention to. Nonetheless, I believe it is possible in under five minutes, so long as the user carefully reads the description, unlike me (lol).

I like the concept of this clash (and really love the name), and I'm giving you a thumbs up.

But please explain the answers of 11 thru 14
I believe it should be this instead of what you have:
11 = wonderful
12 = tiny
13 = worst
14 = ugly
...since you are saying "must find the most important adjective of the **first** noun in the dictionary found in the sentence."

Maybe you mean last?  Or maybe I'm just being dumb.

Goal
* Please change "phrase" to "sentence".

* Please change "carets (-)" to "punctuations".

* Please change "Punctuation ([[.]], [[!]], [[,]])" to "In the output, punctuations ({{.}}, {{!}}, {{,}})".

(Please note the plural form and also the {{constant}} formatting in the changed version.)

* Please change "case-folded (lowercase)" to "in lowercase".

* Please format "day", "DAY" and "dAy" as {{constants}} instead of [[variables]].

* Please mention that a word in the dictionary may be found in the sentence with a punctuation attached to it, e.g. {{day}} may appear in the sentence as {{day.}} or {{day,}}.

Cases
* Please add more pairs of cases where multiple nouns in the dictionary are found in the sentence. With the existing cases, it isn't necessary to identify which noun is the "first found noun".

Stub generator
* Please add a write statement (e.g. "write answer").

Thanks.

Applied everything (and I actually learnt that "punctuation" was quantifiable today), thanks!

Also, you're absolutely right for the "multiple nouns may be present in the sentence", and I forgot to account for that in the cases. So I've added the "Multiple matches" test case and validator, and also added this in the final test.

Thanks for the input!

11. "match" is before "two" in the provided dictionary, so what you're looking for is the most important adjective to "match" first, which is "great".
12. "headphones" is before "cord" in the provided dictionary, so what you're looking for is the most important adjective to "headphones" first, which is "fake".
13. "game" is before "movie" in the provided dictionary, so what you're looking for is the most important adjective to "game" first, which is "STUPID".
14. "guy" is before "moron" in the provided dictionary, so what you're looking for is the most important adjective to "guy" first, which is "sTUPID".

You're not being dumb, the way it's phrased may not be ideal. If you have any idea of how to make the subject clearer to you, please make a suggestion, it may help others!

I see what you mean. Changed it to:

> You're provided with a sentence and a noun dictionary, and must find the adjective closest to the first noun in dictionary order in the sentence.
>
> [...]
>
> The adjective closest to a given noun phrase is always directly before the noun.

Okay, right, I see.

Your phrase "the first noun in the dictionary found in the sentence" could be interpreted two ways:
(1) the way you intended, which is look at all the nouns in the sentence and focus on just the ones that are in the dictionary.  If there is more than one, then focus on the one that comes first in the dictionary
(2) I interpreted as "the first noun ... found in the sentence" if that noun is in the dictionary

As I was trying to figure out a rephrase to suggest, I can't come up with anything. :(  It is hard.  But maybe my feedback will help inspire something in you.
Sooo I've tried something, I've reworded the first sentence and added an additional paragraph with an example (second paragraph). How about now?

Is there some reason you’re not putting your dictionary in alphabetical order… I think that’s throwing me off a little bit too. 

How about dictionary is apple then zebra
Sentence is 
The good zebra ate the bad apple
answer is bad.
Had to move some things around (and simplified my solution), but ok with the dictionary being alphabetically sorted, it's done! :)

Thank you for the changes. The clash looks better now. One more fix:

Goal
* Please change "]" to "{{.}}".

Thanks again.
Oops, not sure how I messed up here. Thanks! :-)
